10870Journal of Chemical CrystallographyJ Chem Crystallogr1074-15421572-8854Springer USBostons10870-010-9842-3984210.1007/s10870-010-9842-3Original PaperSynthesis, Crystal Structure and Magnetic Property of a One-Dimensional Samarium(III) Coordination PolymerLinShuang-Yan12ZhaoLang2XuGong-Feng2GuoYun-Nan2LiuGui-Xia1eTangJinkui2fgrid.440668.8School of Chemistry and Environmental EngineeringChangchun University of Science and Technology130022ChangchunChinagrid.453213.20000000417932912State Key Laboratory of Rare Earth Resource UtilizationChangchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences130022ChangchunChina+86 431 85582574liuguixia22@yahoo.com.cn+86 431 85262878tang@ciac.jl.cn25720101201141177812862010154201028620102572010© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20102010Abstract

A novel samarium(III) polymer, [Sm2(C6H5COO)6(CH3OH)3]·CH3OH (1) has been synthesized and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction and magnetic measurements. Polymer 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P2(1)/c, with a = 15.1247(6), b = 18.3351(7), c = 21.1266(6) Å, β = 126.830(2)°, V = 4689.4(3) Å3, and Z = 4. Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals a chain-like structure of 1 consisted of alternating eight- and nine-coordinate Sm(III) ions bridged by benzoate ligands in different coordination modes. A treatment of the variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility using an expression deduced from free-ion approximation and molecular field theory suggests the existence of a weak antiferromagnetic coupling between the samarium ions.

Graphical Abstract

A novel one-dimensional samarium polymer containing alternating eight- and nine-coordinate Sm(III) ions has been generated by incorporating benzoic acid in three different binding modes in its deprotonated state.

In recent years, the synthesis of lanthanide polymers has aroused much more attention due to their potential useful for a variety of applications ranging from photoluminescent and magnetic materials to their use in homogeneous catalysis [1–3]. As far as magnetism is concerned, most of lanthanide ions with the large intrinsic magnetic anisotropy and large spin moments could be suitable candidates for creating molecular magnetic materials; however, this remains an exciting challenge because of the difficulty in promoting magnetic interactions between the “contracted” 4f orbitals of lanthanide ions [4, 5]. In addition, the explanation for the nature and magnitude of f–f interactions is very complicated, due to the large orbital contributions of most lanthanide ions and the effects of the crystal field.

Benzoic acid and its derivatives have been widely used in the coordination polymers of lanthanide ions because of their intriguing structural features and special physical properties [6, 7]. Since each carboxyl oxygen atom may act as a monodentate or bidentate ligand, the benzoate group binding mode is versatile so that the ligand may coordinate to various kinds of metal ions and produces polynuclear or multidimensional polymers [8–10]. As far as we know, more than seven coordination modes have been structurally characterized for this extremely versatile ligand [6, 11–14]. Herein we present the synthesis and structure of [Sm2(C6H5COO)6(CH3OH)3]·CH3OH (1), in which benzoate groups coordinate in three different modes simultaneously, namely η2-fashion (chelating), syn–syn μ2–η1:η1-fashion (bridging) and μ2–η1:η2-fashion (chelating-bridging), thus generating a 1D array of alternating eight- and nine-coordinate samarium(III) ions.

ExperimentalMaterials and Synthesis

All starting chemicals were of analytical grade and used as received. Samarium benzoate and the Schiff base of 2,6-diformyl-4-methylphenol oxime (H3L) were prepared as described in literatures [15, 16].

The H3L ligand (0.15 mmol, 30.1 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL methanol, then samarium benzoate (0.3 mmol, 157.8 mg) was added under continuously stirring at room temperature. After that, 5 mL tetrahydrofuran (THF) was added and the reaction mixture was left unperturbed to allow the slow evaporation of the solvent. Pale white single crystals, suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis, were obtained after five days. Yield: 29.8 mg (17%, based on the metal). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for 1: C 47.81, H 4.01; found C 47.60, H 3.88.

Physical Measurements

Elemental analysis for C and H were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 2400 analyzer. The IR measurements were performed on a Perkin-Elmer Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrophotometer using the reflectance technique (4,000–300 cm−1), sample was prepared as KBr disks. Magnetic measurements were performed in the temperature range 1.9–300 K, using a Quantum Design MPMSXL-7 SQUID magnetometer equipped with a 7 T magnet. The diamagnetic corrections for the compound were estimated using Pascal’s constants, and magnetic data were corrected for diamagnetic contributions of the sample holder.

X-Ray Crystallography

Suitable single crystal with dimensions of 0.19 × 0.15 × 0.12 mm3 for polymer 1 was selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Crystallographic data were collected at a temperature of 191(2) K on a Bruker ApexII CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data processing was accomplished with the SAINT processing program. The structure was solved by the direct methods and refined on F2 by full-matrix least squares using SHELXTL97 [17, 18]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The H atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined with fixed geometry with respect to their carrier atoms. The crystallographic data are listed in Table 1. CCDC-773111 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html [or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC), 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: (44) 1223-336033; email: deposit@ccdc.ccam.ac.uk].

Results and DiscussionPreparation of Polymer 1

The reaction of samarium(III) benzoate with 2,6-diformyl-4-methylphenol oxime in the mixture of methanol and THF produced the 1D samarium(III) polymer 1. Attempts to grow single crystals of this polymer in the absence of the Schiff base were unsuccessful, indicating that this Schiff base might promote the formation of this polymer.

Spectroscopic Characterization

The infrared spectrum of polymer 1 exhibits bands at 1594, 1538, 1516, 1494, 1424, and 1306 cm−1, which were assigned to asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of the carboxyl group, suggesting that the carboxyl group is coordinated to Sm(III) ion in three coordination modes [13]. However, the bands characteristic of the benzoic acid at about 1,745 cm−1, and in the range of 1,705–685 cm−1, completely disappear in the spectrum of the polymer, indicating that benzoic acid is deprotonated. These features suggested by IR spectrum were corroborated by X-ray diffraction analysis (vide infra).

Description of Crystal Structure

Polymer 1 crystallizes in monoclinic P2(1)/c space group. The view of the molecular structure is shown in Fig. 1 and selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table 2. The asymmetric unit consists of two samarium(III) ions, six benzoates and four methanol molecules. As shown in Fig. 1a, Sm1 and Sm2 are connected together by two μ2–η1:η2 and one μ2–η1:η1 benzoate bridges to form a dinuclear samarium(III) unit with Sm1–Sm2 distance of 5.3758(3) Å. Each dinuclear unit is linked to two adjacent ones through double μ2–η1:η1 benzoate bridges to generate a 1D structure with Sm2–Sm1A distance of 4.0907(3) Å (symmetry code A: 2 − x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 − z). The coordination sphere of Sm1 is completed by a η2 chelating benzoate ligand and a methanol molecule, generating eight-coordinate centre with a distorted trigonal dodecahedral geometry (Fig. 1b), while that of Sm2 is completed by two methanol molecules, adopting a distorted tri-capped trigonal prismatic environment (Fig. 1c).

The above-mentioned three different coordination modes of benzoate groups in the crystal structure (Scheme 1) and the coordination of methanol molecules produce this unique alternating eight- and nine-coordinate samarium 1D array [13, 19, 20]. The average Sm–O bond distance is 2.451 Å, where the shortest Sm–O separation is 2.297(2) Å, resulting from the Sm1–O12 bond from the syn–syn μ2–η1:η1-benzoate oxygen atom, and the longest is the 2.805(2) Å of Sm2–O5A from the μ2–η1:η2-benzoate oxygen atom. Furthermore, one methanol molecule of crystallization is located in the crystal lattice.

Magnetic Property

The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility studies of 1 were carried out in an applied magnetic field of 5,000 Oe in the temperature range of 1.9–300 K. As shown in Fig. 2, The plot of χMT versus T (in which χM is molar magnetic susceptibility) is nearly linear over the whole temperature range, χMT is equal to 0.702 cm3 K mol−1 at 300 K, and decreases rapidly with the temperature to a value of 0.068 cm3 K mol−1 at 2 K, which is slightly smaller than the value of 0.089 cm3 K mol−1 predicted by theory.

Unlike most of free lanthanide ions, the energy separation of Sm(III) ion between the 6H5/2 ground state and the first excited state is so small that the first excited state may be thermally populated. Thus, both the crystal-field effect and the possible thermal population of the higher states should be evaluated for the Sm(III) polymer. According to the treatment of single ion Sm(III) [4, 21, 22], the intrachain coupling constant between Sm(III) can be roughly estimated by the mean-field theory as follows:\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ \begin{gathered} \chi_{\text{Sm}} = \left( {{{N\beta^{2} } \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{N\beta^{2} } {3kTx}}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} {3kTx}}} \right)\left[ {2.143x + 7.347 + \left( {42.92x + 1.641} \right)e^{ - 7x/2} } \right. + \left( {283.7x - 0.6571} \right)e^{ - 8x} \hfill \\ + \left( {620.6x - 1.94} \right)e^{ - 27x/2} + \left( {1122x - 2.835} \right)e^{ - 20x} {{\left. { + \left( {1813x - 3.556} \right)e^{ - 55x/2} } \right]} \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{\left. { + \left( {1.813x - 3.556} \right)e^{ - 55x/2} } \right]} {\left( {3 + 4e^{ - 7x/2} } \right.}}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} {\left( {3 + 4e^{ - 7x/2} } \right.}} \hfill \\ \left. { + 5e^{ - 8x} + 6e^{ - 27x/2} + 7e^{ - 20x} + 8e^{ - 55x/2} } \right) \hfill \\ \chi_{M} = {{\chi_{\text{Sm}} } \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{\chi_{\text{Sm}} } {\left[ {1 - \left( {{{2z_{j} '} \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{2z_{j} '} {Ng_{J}^{2} \beta^{2} }}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} {Ng_{J}^{2} \beta^{2} }}} \right)\chi_{\text{Sm}} } \right]}}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} {\left[ {1 - \left( {{{2z_{j} '} \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{2z_{j} '} {Ng_{J}^{2} \beta^{2} }}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} {Ng_{J}^{2} \beta^{2} }}} \right)\chi_{\text{Sm}} } \right]}} \hfill \\ \end{gathered} $$\end{document}where x = λ/kT, gJ is the Landé factor, and fixed as the theoretical value of 0.289, λ is the spin-orbit coupling parameter, and zj′ is the coupling interaction between Sm(III) ions within chain. The best fitting results gave: λ = 217, and zj′ = −1.32 cm−1 with R2 = 0.998. The negative value of zj′ indicates the weak antiferromagnetic coupling between Sm(III) ions in the polymer.

Conclusion

To summarize, a one-dimensional samarium array containing alternating eight- and nine-coordinate Sm(III) ions has been generated by incorporating benzoic acid in three different binding modes in its deprotonated state. Magnetic analysis indicates weak antiferromagnetic coupling between Sm(III) ions. The design of new lanthanide arrays using more anisotropic ions, such as Dy(III), Tb(III) and Ho(III) is under way in our group.

Acknowledgments

We thank the Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry (Start-up) and the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grants 20871113 and 20921002) for their financial support.

The best fitting results gave: λ = 217, and zj' = -1.32 cm-1 with R2 = 0.998. The negative value of zj' indicates the weak antiferromagnetic coupling between Sm(III) ions in the polymer.ConclusionTo summarize, a one-dimensional samarium array containing alternating eight- and nine-coordinate Sm(III) ions has been generated by incorporating benzoic acid in three different binding modes in its deprotonated state. Magnetic analysis indicates weak antiferromagnetic coupling between Sm(III) ions. The design of new lanthanide arrays using more anisotropic ions, such as Dy(III), Tb(III) and Ho(III) is under way in our group.AcknowledgmentsWe thank the Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry elements.content: A novel samarium(III) polymer, [Sm2(C6H5COO)6(CH3OH)3]·CH3OH (1) has been synthesized and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction and magnetic measurements. Polymer 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P2(1)/c, with a = 15.1247(6), b = 18.3351(7), c = 21.1266(6) Å, β = 126.830(2)°, V = 4689.4(3) Å3, and Z = 4. Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals a chain-like structure of 1 consisted of alternating eight- and nine-coordinate Sm(III) ions bridged by benzoate ligands in different coordination modes. A treatment of the variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility using an expression deduced from free-ion approximation and molecular field theory suggests the existence of a weak antiferromagnetic coupling between the samarium ions.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel samarium(III) polymer, [Sm2(C6H5COO)6(CH3OH)3]⋅CH3OH (1) has been synthesized and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction and magnetic measurements. Polymer 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P2(1)/c, with a = 15.1247(6), b = 18.3351(7), c = 21.1266(6) Å, β = 126.830(2)°, V = 4689.4(3) Å3, and Z = 4. Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals a chain-like structure of 1 consisted of alternating eight- and nine-coordinate Sm(III) ions bridged by benzoate ligands in different coordination modes. A treatment of the variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility using an expression deduced from free-ion approximation and molecular field theory suggests the existence of a weak antiferromagnetic coupling between the samarium ions.

elements.content: A novel one-dimensional samarium polymer containing alternating eight- and nine-coordinate Sm(III) ions has been generated by incorporating benzoic acid in three different binding modes in its deprotonated state.
elements.clean_text:
Graphical Abstract

A novel one-dimensional samarium polymer containing alternating eight- and nine-coordinate Sm(III) ions has been generated by incorporating benzoic acid in three different binding modes in its deprotonated state.

elements.content: In recent years, the synthesis of lanthanide polymers has aroused much more attention due to their potential useful for a variety of applications ranging from photoluminescent and magnetic materials to their use in homogeneous catalysis [1–3]. As far as magnetism is concerned, most of lanthanide ions with the large intrinsic magnetic anisotropy and large spin moments could be suitable candidates for creating molecular magnetic materials; however, this remains an exciting challenge because of the difficulty in promoting magnetic interactions between the “contracted” 4f orbitals of lanthanide ions [4, 5]. In addition, the explanation for the nature and magnitude of f–f interactions is very complicated, due to the large orbital contributions of most lanthanide ions and the effects of the crystal field.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, the synthesis of lanthanide polymers has aroused much more attention due to their potential useful for a variety of applications ranging from photoluminescent and magnetic materials to their use in homogeneous catalysis [1-3]. As far as magnetism is concerned, most of lanthanide ions with the large intrinsic magnetic anisotropy and large spin moments could be suitable candidates for creating molecular magnetic materials; however, this remains an exciting challenge because of the difficulty in promoting magnetic interactions between the "contracted" 4f orbitals of lanthanide ions [4, 5]. In addition, the explanation for the nature and magnitude of f-f interactions is very complicated, due to the large orbital contributions of most lanthanide ions and the effects of the crystal field.

elements.content: Benzoic acid and its derivatives have been widely used in the coordination polymers of lanthanide ions because of their intriguing structural features and special physical properties [6, 7]. Since each carboxyl oxygen atom may act as a monodentate or bidentate ligand, the benzoate group binding mode is versatile so that the ligand may coordinate to various kinds of metal ions and produces polynuclear or multidimensional polymers [8–10]. As far as we know, more than seven coordination modes have been structurally characterized for this extremely versatile ligand [6, 11–14]. Herein we present the synthesis and structure of [Sm2(C6H5COO)6(CH3OH)3]·CH3OH (1), in which benzoate groups coordinate in three different modes simultaneously, namely η2-fashion (chelating), syn–syn μ2–η1:η1-fashion (bridging) and μ2–η1:η2-fashion (chelating-bridging), thus generating a 1D array of alternating eight- and nine-coordinate samarium(III) ions.
elements.clean_text: Benzoic acid and its derivatives have been widely used in the coordination polymers of lanthanide ions because of their intriguing structural features and special physical properties [6, 7]. Since each carboxyl oxygen atom may act as a monodentate or bidentate ligand, the benzoate group binding mode is versatile so that the ligand may coordinate to various kinds of metal ions and produces polynuclear or multidimensional polymers [8-10]. As far as we know, more than seven coordination modes have been structurally characterized for this extremely versatile ligand [6, 11-14]. Herein we present the synthesis and structure of [Sm2(C6H5COO)6(CH3OH)3]⋅CH3OH (1), in which benzoate groups coordinate in three different modes simultaneously, namely η2-fashion (chelating), syn-syn μ2-η1:η1-fashion (bridging) and μ2-η1:η2-fashion (chelating-bridging), thus generating a 1D array of alternating eight- and nine-coordinate samarium(III) ions.

elements.content: All starting chemicals were of analytical grade and used as received. Samarium benzoate and the Schiff base of 2,6-diformyl-4-methylphenol oxime (H3L) were prepared as described in literatures [15, 16].
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and Synthesis

All starting chemicals were of analytical grade and used as received. Samarium benzoate and the Schiff base of 2,6-diformyl-4-methylphenol oxime (H3L) were prepared as described in literatures [15, 16].

elements.content: The H3L ligand (0.15 mmol, 30.1 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL methanol, then samarium benzoate (0.3 mmol, 157.8 mg) was added under continuously stirring at room temperature. After that, 5 mL tetrahydrofuran (THF) was added and the reaction mixture was left unperturbed to allow the slow evaporation of the solvent. Pale white single crystals, suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis, were obtained after five days. Yield: 29.8 mg (17%, based on the metal). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for 1: C 47.81, H 4.01; found C 47.60, H 3.88.
elements.clean_text: The H3L ligand (0.15 mmol, 30.1 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL methanol, then samarium benzoate (0.3 mmol, 157.8 mg) was added under continuously stirring at room temperature. After that, 5 mL tetrahydrofuran (THF) was added and the reaction mixture was left unperturbed to allow the slow evaporation of the solvent. Pale white single crystals, suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis, were obtained after five days. Yield: 29.8 mg (17%, based on the metal). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for 1: C 47.81, H 4.01; found C 47.60, H 3.88.

elements.content: Elemental analysis for C and H were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 2400 analyzer. The IR measurements were performed on a Perkin-Elmer Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrophotometer using the reflectance technique (4,000–300 cm−1), sample was prepared as KBr disks. Magnetic measurements were performed in the temperature range 1.9–300 K, using a Quantum Design MPMSXL-7 SQUID magnetometer equipped with a 7 T magnet. The diamagnetic corrections for the compound were estimated using Pascal’s constants, and magnetic data were corrected for diamagnetic contributions of the sample holder.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

Elemental analysis for C and H were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 2400 analyzer. The IR measurements were performed on a Perkin-Elmer Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrophotometer using the reflectance technique (4,000-300 cm-1), sample was prepared as KBr disks. Magnetic measurements were performed in the temperature range 1.9-300 K, using a Quantum Design MPMSXL-7 SQUID magnetometer equipped with a 7 T magnet. The diamagnetic corrections for the compound were estimated using Pascal's constants, and magnetic data were corrected for diamagnetic contributions of the sample holder.

elements.content: Suitable single crystal with dimensions of 0.19 × 0.15 × 0.12 mm3 for polymer 1 was selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Crystallographic data were collected at a temperature of 191(2) K on a Bruker ApexII CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data processing was accomplished with the SAINT processing program. The structure was solved by the direct methods and refined on F2 by full-matrix least squares using SHELXTL97 [17, 18]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The H atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined with fixed geometry with respect to their carrier atoms. The crystallographic data are listed in Table 1. CCDC-773111 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html [or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC), 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: (44) 1223-336033; email: deposit@ccdc.ccam.ac.uk].
elements.clean_text:
X-Ray Crystallography

Suitable single crystal with dimensions of 0.19 × 0.15 × 0.12 mm3 for polymer 1 was selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Crystallographic data were collected at a temperature of 191(2) K on a Bruker ApexII CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data processing was accomplished with the SAINT processing program. The structure was solved by the direct methods and refined on F2 by full-matrix least squares using SHELXTL97 [17, 18]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The H atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined with fixed geometry with respect to their carrier atoms. The crystallographic data are listed in Table 1. CCDC-773111 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html [or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC), 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: (44) 1223-336033; email: deposit@ccdc.ccam.ac.uk].

The reaction of samarium(III) benzoate with 2,6-diformyl-4-methylphenol oxime in the mixture of methanol and THF produced the 1D samarium(III) polymer 1. Attempts to grow single crystals of this polymer in the absence of the Schiff base were unsuccessful, indicating that this Schiff base might promote the formation of this polymer.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Preparation of Polymer 1

The reaction of samarium(III) benzoate with 2,6-diformyl-4-methylphenol oxime in the mixture of methanol and THF produced the 1D samarium(III) polymer 1. Attempts to grow single crystals of this polymer in the absence of the Schiff base were unsuccessful, indicating that this Schiff base might promote the formation of this polymer.

elements.content: The infrared spectrum of polymer 1 exhibits bands at 1594, 1538, 1516, 1494, 1424, and 1306 cm−1, which were assigned to asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of the carboxyl group, suggesting that the carboxyl group is coordinated to Sm(III) ion in three coordination modes [13]. However, the bands characteristic of the benzoic acid at about 1,745 cm−1, and in the range of 1,705–685 cm−1, completely disappear in the spectrum of the polymer, indicating that benzoic acid is deprotonated. These features suggested by IR spectrum were corroborated by X-ray diffraction analysis (vide infra).
elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopic Characterization

The infrared spectrum of polymer 1 exhibits bands at 1594, 1538, 1516, 1494, 1424, and 1306 cm-1, which were assigned to asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of the carboxyl group, suggesting that the carboxyl group is coordinated to Sm(III) ion in three coordination modes [13]. However, the bands characteristic of the benzoic acid at about 1,745 cm-1, and in the range of 1,705-685 cm-1, completely disappear in the spectrum of the polymer, indicating that benzoic acid is deprotonated. These features suggested by IR spectrum were corroborated by X-ray diffraction analysis (vide infra).

elements.content: Polymer 1 crystallizes in monoclinic P2(1)/c space group. The view of the molecular structure is shown in Fig. 1 and selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table 2. The asymmetric unit consists of two samarium(III) ions, six benzoates and four methanol molecules. As shown in Fig. 1a, Sm1 and Sm2 are connected together by two μ2–η1:η2 and one μ2–η1:η1 benzoate bridges to form a dinuclear samarium(III) unit with Sm1–Sm2 distance of 5.3758(3) Å. Each dinuclear unit is linked to two adjacent ones through double μ2–η1:η1 benzoate bridges to generate a 1D structure with Sm2–Sm1A distance of 4.0907(3) Å (symmetry code A: 2 − x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 − z). The coordination sphere of Sm1 is completed by a η2 chelating benzoate ligand and a methanol molecule, generating eight-coordinate centre with a distorted trigonal dodecahedral geometry (Fig. 1b), while that of Sm2 is completed by two methanol molecules, adopting a distorted tri-capped trigonal prismatic environment (Fig. 1c).
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structure

Polymer 1 crystallizes in monoclinic P2(1)/c space group. The view of the molecular structure is shown in Fig. 1 and selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table 2. The asymmetric unit consists of two samarium(III) ions, six benzoates and four methanol molecules. As shown in Fig. 1a, Sm1 and Sm2 are connected together by two μ2-η1:η2 and one μ2-η1:η1 benzoate bridges to form a dinuclear samarium(III) unit with Sm1-Sm2 distance of 5.3758(3) Å. Each dinuclear unit is linked to two adjacent ones through double μ2-η1:η1 benzoate bridges to generate a 1D structure with Sm2-Sm1A distance of 4.0907(3) Å (symmetry code A: 2 - x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 - z). The coordination sphere of Sm1 is completed by a η2 chelating benzoate ligand and a methanol molecule, generating eight-coordinate centre with a distorted trigonal dodecahedral geometry (Fig. 1b), while that of Sm2 is completed by two methanol molecules, adopting a distorted tri-capped trigonal prismatic environment (Fig. 1c).

elements.content: To summarize, a one-dimensional samarium array containing alternating eight- and nine-coordinate Sm(III) ions has been generated by incorporating benzoic acid in three different binding modes in its deprotonated state. Magnetic analysis indicates weak antiferromagnetic coupling between Sm(III) ions. The design of new lanthanide arrays using more anisotropic ions, such as Dy(III), Tb(III) and Ho(III) is under way in our group.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

To summarize, a one-dimensional samarium array containing alternating eight- and nine-coordinate Sm(III) ions has been generated by incorporating benzoic acid in three different binding modes in its deprotonated state. Magnetic analysis indicates weak antiferromagnetic coupling between Sm(III) ions. The design of new lanthanide arrays using more anisotropic ions, such as Dy(III), Tb(III) and Ho(III) is under way in our group.

cln_elements.content: The H3L ligand (0.15 mmol, 30.1 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL methanol, then samarium benzoate (0.3 mmol, 157.8 mg) was added under continuously stirring at room temperature. After that, 5 mL tetrahydrofuran (THF) was added and the reaction mixture was left unperturbed to allow the slow evaporation of the solvent. Pale white single crystals, suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis, were obtained after five days. Yield: 29.8 mg (17%, based on the metal). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for 1: C 47.81, H 4.01; found C 47.60, H 3.88.

A novel samarium(III) polymer, [Sm2(C6H5COO)6(CH3OH)3]·CH3OH (1) has been synthesized and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction and magnetic measurements. Polymer 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P2(1)/c, with a = 15.1247(6), b = 18.3351(7), c = 21.1266(6) Å, β = 126.830(2)°, V = 4689.4(3) Å3, and Z = 4. Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals a chain-like structure of 1 consisted of alternating eight- and nine-coordinate Sm(III) ions bridged by benzoate ligands in different coordination modes. A treatment of the variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility using an expression deduced from free-ion approximation and molecular field theory suggests the existence of a weak antiferromagnetic coupling between the samarium ions.

The above-mentioned three different coordination modes of benzoate groups in the crystal structure (Scheme 1) and the coordination of methanol molecules produce this unique alternating eight- and nine-coordinate samarium 1D array [13, 19, 20]. The average Sm–O bond distance is 2.451 Å, where the shortest Sm–O separation is 2.297(2) Å, resulting from the Sm1–O12 bond from the syn–syn μ2–η1:η1-benzoate oxygen atom, and the longest is the 2.805(2) Å of Sm2–O5A from the μ2–η1:η2-benzoate oxygen atom. Furthermore, one methanol molecule of crystallization is located in the crystal lattice.

Magnetic Property

The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility studies of 1 were carried out in an applied magnetic field of 5,000 Oe in the temperature range of 1.9–300 K. As shown in Fig. 2, The plot of χMT versus T (in which χM is molar magnetic susceptibility) is nearly linear over the whole temperature range, χMT is equal to 0.702 cm3 K mol−1 at 300 K, and decreases rapidly with the temperature to a value of 0.068 cm3 K mol−1 at 2 K, which is slightly smaller than the value of 0.089 cm3 K mol−1 predicted by theory.

Unlike most of free lanthanide ions, the energy separation of Sm(III) ion between the 6H5/2 ground state and the first excited state is so small that the first excited state may be thermally populated. Thus, both the crystal-field effect and the possible thermal population of the higher states should be evaluated for the Sm(III) polymer. According to the treatment of single ion Sm(III) [4, 21, 22], the intrachain coupling constant between Sm(III) can be roughly estimated by the mean-field theory as follows:\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ \begin{gathered} \chi_{\text{Sm}} = \left( {{{N\beta^{2} } \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{N\beta^{2} } {3kTx}}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} {3kTx}}} \right)\left[ {2.143x + 7.347 + \left( {42.92x + 1.641} \right)e^{ - 7x/2} } \right. + \left( {283.7x - 0.6571} \right)e^{ - 8x} \hfill \\ + \left( {620.6x - 1.94} \right)e^{ - 27x/2} + \left( {1122x - 2.835} \right)e^{ - 20x} {{\left. { + \left( {1813x - 3.556} \right)e^{ - 55x/2} } \right]} \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{\left. { + \left( {1.813x - 3.556} \right)e^{ - 55x/2} } \right]} {\left( {3 + 4e^{ - 7x/2} } \right.}}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} {\left( {3 + 4e^{ - 7x/2} } \right.}} \hfill \\ \left. { + 5e^{ - 8x} + 6e^{ - 27x/2} + 7e^{ - 20x} + 8e^{ - 55x/2} } \right) \hfill \\ \chi_{M} = {{\chi_{\text{Sm}} } \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{\chi_{\text{Sm}} } {\left[ {1 - \left( {{{2z_{j} '} \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{2z_{j} '} {Ng_{J}^{2} \beta^{2} }}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} {Ng_{J}^{2} \beta^{2} }}} \right)\chi_{\text{Sm}} } \right]}}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} {\left[ {1 - \left( {{{2z_{j} '} \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{2z_{j} '} {Ng_{J}^{2} \beta^{2} }}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} {Ng_{J}^{2} \beta^{2} }}} \right)\chi_{\text{Sm}} } \right]}} \hfill \\ \end{gathered} $$\end{document}where x = λ/kT, gJ is the Landé factor, and fixed as the theoretical value of 0.289, λ is the spin-orbit coupling parameter, and zj′ is the coupling interaction between Sm(III) ions within chain. The best fitting results gave: λ = 217, and zj′ = −1.32 cm−1 with R2 = 0.998. The negative value of zj′ indicates the weak antiferromagnetic coupling between Sm(III) ions in the polymer.

Abstract

A novel samarium(III) polymer, [Sm2(C6H5COO)6(CH3OH)3]⋅CH3OH (1) has been synthesized and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction and magnetic measurements. Polymer 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P2(1)/c, with a = 15.1247(6), b = 18.3351(7), c = 21.1266(6) Å, β = 126.830(2)°, V = 4689.4(3) Å3, and Z = 4. Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals a chain-like structure of 1 consisted of alternating eight- and nine-coordinate Sm(III) ions bridged by benzoate ligands in different coordination modes. A treatment of the variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility using an expression deduced from free-ion approximation and molecular field theory suggests the existence of a weak antiferromagnetic coupling between the samarium ions.

The above-mentioned three different coordination modes of benzoate groups in the crystal structure (Scheme 1) and the coordination of methanol molecules produce this unique alternating eight- and nine-coordinate samarium 1D array [13, 19, 20]. The average Sm-O bond distance is 2.451 Å, where the shortest Sm-O separation is 2.297(2) Å, resulting from the Sm1-O12 bond from the syn-syn μ2-η1:η1-benzoate oxygen atom, and the longest is the 2.805(2) Å of Sm2-O5A from the μ2-η1:η2-benzoate oxygen atom. Furthermore, one methanol molecule of crystallization is located in the crystal lattice.

Magnetic Property

The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility studies of 1 were carried out in an applied magnetic field of 5,000 Oe in the temperature range of 1.9-300 K. As shown in Fig. 2, The plot of χMT versus T (in which χM is molar magnetic susceptibility) is nearly linear over the whole temperature range, χMT is equal to 0.702 cm3 K mol-1 at 300 K, and decreases rapidly with the temperature to a value of 0.068 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, which is slightly smaller than the value of 0.089 cm3 K mol-1 predicted by theory.

Unlike most of free lanthanide ions, the energy separation of Sm(III) ion between the 6H5/2 ground state and the first excited state is so small that the first excited state may be thermally populated. Thus, both the crystal-field effect and the possible thermal population of the higher states should be evaluated for the Sm(III) polymer. According to the treatment of single ion Sm(III) [4, 21, 22], the intrachain coupling constant between Sm(III) can be roughly estimated by the mean-field theory as follows:\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$ \begin{gathered} \chi_{\text{Sm}} = \left( {{{N\beta^{2} } \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{N\beta^{2} } {3kTx}}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} {3kTx}}} \right)\left[ {2.143x + 7.347 + \left( {42.92x + 1.641} \right)e^{ - 7x/2} } \right. + \left( {283.7x - 0.6571} \right)e^{ - 8x} \hfill \\ + \left( {620.6x - 1.94} \right)e^{ - 27x/2} + \left( {1122x - 2.835} \right)e^{ - 20x} {{\left. { + \left( {1813x - 3.556} \right)e^{ - 55x/2} } \right]} \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{\left. { + \left( {1.813x - 3.556} \right)e^{ - 55x/2} } \right]} {\left( {3 + 4e^{ - 7x/2} } \right.}}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} {\left( {3 + 4e^{ - 7x/2} } \right.}} \hfill \\ \left. { + 5e^{ - 8x} + 6e^{ - 27x/2} + 7e^{ - 20x} + 8e^{ - 55x/2} } \right) \hfill \\ \chi_{M} = {{\chi_{\text{Sm}} } \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{\chi_{\text{Sm}} } {\left[ {1 - \left( {{{2z_{j} '} \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{2z_{j} '} {Ng_{J}^{2} \beta^{2} }}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} {Ng_{J}^{2} \beta^{2} }}} \right)\chi_{\text{Sm}} } \right]}}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} {\left[ {1 - \left( {{{2z_{j} '} \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{2z_{j} '} {Ng_{J}^{2} \beta^{2} }}} \right. \kern-\nulldelimiterspace} {Ng_{J}^{2} \beta^{2} }}} \right)\chi_{\text{Sm}} } \right]}} \hfill \\ \end{gathered} $$\end{document}where x = λ/kT, gJ is the Landé factor, and fixed as the theoretical value of 0.289, λ is the spin-orbit coupling parameter, and zj' is the coupling interaction between Sm(III) ions within chain. The best fitting results gave: λ = 217, and zj' = -1.32 cm-1 with R2 = 0.998. The negative value of zj' indicates the weak antiferromagnetic coupling between Sm(III) ions in the polymer.
